message:
Heya,

Thanks for this series of posts! You have a couple comments about (almost) never using BackgroundWorker (although you do mnention it might be ok in synchronous work)

I'm wondering if I might be in an instance where using BackgroundWorker does make sense. This is for a Windows Phone 8.1 SL app.

1. (async) Get a list of images

2. (async) Download the first thumbnail

3. Fire off a background thread to download the high-quality version of the first image (granted, the downloading and storing are async methods, but it's ok for this thread to block by using .Result)

4. (async) Download all the other thumbnails

In this case, if I use await Task.Run() in step 3, the requests in step 4 won't start until after step 3 finishes. However, calling RunWorkerAsync allows the containing method to continue and grab the other thumbnails while the large image downloads.

Does this make sense, or am I missing something about how Task.Run works?

Many thanks,

Jedidja

First, from this description, there's nothing CPU-bound that the code is doing. So there should be a straightforward way to do this without BGW or Task.Run at all.

In general, you can start an async operation by just calling the method and not doing an await right away; instead, just save the Task in a variable and await it later (possibly using Task.WhenAll or Task.WhenAny).

That same strategy can be used with Task.Run, but again it sounds like there would be a better solution without Task.Run or BGW at all.

Ohhh...yes I think I remember stumbling across a similar sample in MSDN at some point. So basically I could create a bunch of Tasks and then await on WhenAll (which in the background is going to spin some/all of them up using a similar method to Parallel.ForEach)?

I've really enjoyed your articles and all your helpful answers on StackOverflow - thanks! Although I've been developing in .Net for a while, I haven't had the chance to really use this part of the framework until now working on my own Windows Phone app.
Ah ok. Definitely something I need to play with a bit more to really get my head wrapped around. Thanks again for being so patient with people asking very similar questions over and over again :)

Thanks, this BackgroundWorker sucks!! I'm stuck since 3 days because of it, I can't make it through a 'for' loop, it always completes before. I'm going to read more about async.  
Thanks again

I know you wrote this over 9 years ago but just wanted to let you know....your effort is still paying dividends.    I have been a BackgroundWorker fan my whole c# career....until I stumbled across this blog post.  

WOW - you explained it so simply.  And while I'm still wrapping my head around how to do everything I used to do with BackgroundWorker - I have begun to use Task.Run exclusively going forward.    Very cool alternative to BackgroundWorker. 

Thank you for taking the time to post this.    I advise any other BackgroundWorker fans out there to give this a try.   You won't be sorry.
Thanks for the kind words! I'm glad you found it helpful!

found this page from stackoverflow.com/questions/58760448/is-there-a-modern-equivalent-to-the-vb6-winsock-control-in-visual-studio-net

i try read doc about winsocket then what i found, he tell background worker is dead. We are in 2022 with upcoming .Net Core 7.0 on roadmap. Start learning .net from 2014. Thank You. Now i can leave in peace.

To echo what others have said, and yet later in time: thanks for this very clear and useful comparison/conversion guide! It's helped me convert a BackgroundWorker in a legacy application into async/await syntax, so that I could then nest a timeout-cancellable async call to an Excel Interop component which was hanging the application when trying to open .xlsx files over an unreliable network connection.

The critical problem I was having you've mentioned right on this first page: "BackgroundWorker doesnâ€™t work well with async code. An async DoWork handler will exit early, causing the RunWorkerCompleted to fire before the method is completed."

Found the link to this intro from your answer on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61216810/run-async-await-task-in-backgroundworkers-runworkercompleted
